document_title: Effects of spaceflight on cancellous and cortical bone in proximal femur in growing rats
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on bone microarchitecture in the proximal femur of growing rats across three different missions (STS-41, STS-57, and STS-62), varying in duration, age, sex, and strain. Using micro-computed tomography (Î¼CT), the researchers assessed cancellous bone volume fraction and cortical thickness. Findings indicate that spaceflight consistently leads to cancellous osteopenia in the femoral head of growing rats, observed in both male Sprague Dawley and Fisher 344 rats, as well as in ovariectomized female Fisher 344 rats. While cancellous bone volume fraction was significantly reduced in flight animals compared to controls in some groups, cortical thickness remained largely unaffected. The study concludes that spaceflight induces cancellous osteopenia in the femoral head, a clinically relevant site for fractures in humans, and suggests this site warrants further investigation in future spaceflight research.
key_findings: Spaceflight causes cancellous osteopenia (reduced bone volume fraction) in the femoral head of growing rats.
This effect was observed across different rat strains (Sprague Dawley, Fisher 344), sexes (male and ovariectomized female), and mission durations (4, 10, and 14 days).
Cancellous bone volume fraction in the femoral head was significantly lower in flight animals compared to ground controls in some experimental groups.
Cortical thickness in the proximal femur diaphysis did not differ significantly among spaceflight, flight control, and baseline groups.
In ovariectomized female rats, spaceflight led to net bone loss in the femoral head compared to both flight controls and baseline.
The proximal femur, a site prone to fractures in humans, is particularly susceptible to spaceflight-induced bone loss.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying spaceflight-induced cancellous osteopenia in the proximal femur.
Evaluating the long-term effects of spaceflight on bone recovery and adaptation in the proximal femur.
Exploring countermeasures to mitigate bone loss in the proximal femur during space missions.
Assessing the impact of spaceflight on the mechanical competence and fracture risk of the proximal femur.
Comparing the skeletal response to spaceflight in skeletally mature animals versus growing animals.

conclusions: Spaceflight, even for short durations (4-14 days), consistently results in cancellous osteopenia in the femoral head of growing rats across different strains and sexes. While cortical bone thickness is not significantly affected, the loss of cancellous bone in this clinically relevant site suggests an increased risk of fracture under microgravity conditions. These findings underscore the importance of evaluating the proximal femur in future spaceflight studies.
impact_statement: This research demonstrates that spaceflight induces bone loss in a critical region of the femur, highlighting a potential health risk for astronauts and informing strategies for maintaining skeletal integrity in space.
